column2: Be done, boys!	Be done, boys!
Who's there?"
column3: Who's there?"

column2: I says:
column3: I says:

column2: Who's me?
column3: Who's me?

column2: George Jackson, sir.
column3: George Jackson, sir.

column2: What do you want?
column3: What do you want?

column2: I don't want nothing, sir.	I don't want nothing, sir.
I warn't prowling around, sir, I fell overboard off of the steamboat.
column3: I warn't prowling around, sir, I fell overboard off of the steamboat.

column2: Oh, you did, did you?	Oh, you did, did you?
Strike a light there, somebody.
column3: Strike a light there, somebody.

column2: George Jackson, sir.	George Jackson, sir.
I'm only a boy."
column3: I'm only a boy."

column2: Look here, if you're telling the truth you needn't be afraidnobody'll hurt you.	Look here, if you're telling the truth you needn't be afraid  nobody'll hurt you.
But don't try to budge; stand right where you are.
column3: But don't try to budge; stand right where you are.

column2: Rouse out Bob and Tom, some of you, and fetch the guns.
column3: Rouse out Bob and Tom, some of you, and fetch the guns.

column2: George Jackson, is there anybody with you?"
column3: George Jackson, is there anybody with you?"

column2: No, sir, nobody.
column3: No, sir, nobody.

column2: I heard the people stirring around in the house now, and see a light. The man sung out:
column3: I heard the people stirring around in the house now, and see a light. The man sung out:

column2: Snatch that light away, Betsy, you old foolain't you got any sense? Put it on the floor behind the front door.	Snatch that light away, Betsy, you old fool  ain't you got any sense? Put it on the floor behind the front door.
Bob, if you and Tom are ready, take your places."
column3: Bob, if you and Tom are ready, take your places."

column2: All ready.
column3: All ready.

column2: Now, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?
column3: Now, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?

column2: No, sir; I never heard of them.
column3: No, sir; I never heard of them.

column2: Now, all ready.
column3: Now, all ready.

column2: Step forward, George Jackson.
column3: Step forward, George Jackson.

column2: If there's anybody with you, let him keep backif he shows himself he'll be shot. Come along now.
column3: If there's anybody with you, let him keep back  if he shows himself he'll be shot. Come along now.

column2: I took one slow step at a time and there warn't a sound, only I thought I could hear my heart. The dogs were as still as the humans, but they followed a little behind me.
column3: I took one slow step at a time and there warn't a sound, only I thought I could hear my heart. The dogs were as still as the humans, but they followed a little behind me.

column2: When I got to the three log doorsteps I heard them unlocking and unbarring and unbolting.
column3: When I got to the three log doorsteps I heard them unlocking and unbarring and unbolting.

column2: There; I reckon it's all right.	There; I reckon it's all right.
Come in."
column3: Come in."

column2: So he didn't pry into my pockets, but only felt outside with his hands, and said it was all right.
column3: So he didn't pry into my pockets, but only felt outside with his hands, and said it was all right.

column2: He told me to make myself easy and at home, and tell all about myself; but the old lady says:
column3: He told me to make myself easy and at home, and tell all about myself; but the old lady says:

column2: True for you, RachelI forgot.
column3: True for you, Rachel  I forgot.

column2: Betsy (this was a nigger woman), "you fly around and get him something to eat as quick as you can, poor thing; and one of you girls go and wake up Buck and tell himoh, here he is himself.
column3: Betsy (this was a nigger woman), "you fly around and get him something to eat as quick as you can, poor thing; and one of you girls go and wake up Buck and tell him  oh, here he is himself.

column2: Buck, take this little stranger and get the wet clothes off from him and dress him up in some of yours that's dry."
column3: Buck, take this little stranger and get the wet clothes off from him and dress him up in some of yours that's dry."

column2: Buck looked about as old as methirteen or fourteen or along there, though he was a little bigger than me.
column3: Buck looked about as old as me  thirteen or fourteen or along there, though he was a little bigger than me.

column2: He hadn't on anything but a shirt, and he was very frowzy-headed.
column3: He hadn't on anything but a shirt, and he was very frowzy headed.

column2: Ain't they no Shepherdsons around?
column3: Ain't they no Shepherdsons around?

column2: They said, no, 'twas a false alarm.
column3: They said, no, 'twas a false alarm.

column2: Well, he says, "if they'd a ben some, I reckon I'd a got one."
column3: Well, he says, "if they'd a ben some, I reckon I'd a got one."

column2: They all laughed, and Bob says:
column3: They all laughed, and Bob says:

column2: Why, Buck, they might have scalped us all, you've been so slow in coming.
column3: Why, Buck, they might have scalped us all, you've been so slow in coming.

column2: Well, nobody come after me, and it ain't right I'm always kept down; I don't get no show.
column3: Well, nobody come after me, and it ain't right I'm always kept down; I don't get no show.

column2: Go 'long with you now, and do as your mother told you."
column3: Go 'long with you now, and do as your mother told you."

column2: When we got up-stairs to his room he got me a coarse shirt and a roundabout and pants of his, and I put them on.
column3: When we got up stairs to his room he got me a coarse shirt and a roundabout and pants of his, and I put them on.

column2: Well, guess, he says.
column3: Well, guess, he says.

column2: But you can guess, can't you?	But you can guess, can't you?
It's just as easy."
column3: It's just as easy."

column2: Why, any candle, he says.
column3: Why, any candle, he says.

column2: I don't know where he was, says I; "where was he?"
column3: I don't know where he was, says I; "where was he?"

column2: That's where he was!"
column3: That's where he was!"

column2: Well, if you knowed where he was, what did you ask me for?
column3: Well, if you knowed where he was, what did you ask me for?

column2: Why, blame it, it's a riddle, don't you see?	Why, blame it, it's a riddle, don't you see?
You got to stay always.
column3: You got to stay always.

column2: Do you own a dog?
column3: Do you own a dog?

column2: Do you like to comb up Sundays, and all that kind of foolishness?
column3: Do you like to comb up Sundays, and all that kind of foolishness?

column2: I reckon I'd better put 'em on, but I'd ruther not, it's so warm.
column3: I reckon I'd better put 'em on, but I'd ruther not, it's so warm.

column2: Are you all ready?
column3: Are you all ready?

column2: All right.
column3: All right.

column2: Cold corn-pone, cold corn-beef, butter and buttermilkthat is what they had for me down there, and there ain't nothing better that ever I've come across yet.
column3: Cold corn pone, cold corn beef, butter and buttermilk  that is what they had for me down there, and there ain't nothing better that ever I've come across yet.

column2: They all smoked and talked, and I eat and talked.
column3: They all smoked and talked, and I eat and talked.

column2: The young women had quilts around them, and their hair down their backs.
column3: The young women had quilts around them, and their hair down their backs.

column2: So I laid there about an hour trying to think, and when Buck waked up I says:
column3: So I laid there about an hour trying to think, and when Buck waked up I says:

column2: Can you spell, Buck?
column3: Can you spell, Buck?

column2: Yes, he says.
column3: Yes, he says.

column2: I bet you can't spell my name, says I.
column3: I bet you can't spell my name, says i

column2: I bet you what you dare I can, says he.
column3: I bet you what you dare I can, says he.

column2: All right, says I, "go ahead."
column3: All right, says I, "go ahead."

column2: G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-nthere now, he says.
column3: G e o r g e J a x o n  there now, he says.

column2: Well, says I, "you done it, but I didn't think you could.
column3: Well, says I, "you done it, but I didn't think you could.

column2: It was a mighty nice family, and a mighty nice house, too.
column3: It was a mighty nice family, and a mighty nice house, too.

column2: There was a big fireplace that was bricked on the bottom, and the bricks was kept clean and red by pouring water on them and scrubbing them with another brick; sometimes they wash them over with red water-paint that they call Spanish-brown, same as they do in town.
column3: There was a big fireplace that was bricked on the bottom, and the bricks was kept clean and red by pouring water on them and scrubbing them with another brick; sometimes they wash them over with red water paint that they call Spanish brown, same as they do in town.

column2: They had big brass dog-irons that could hold up a saw-log.
column3: They had big brass dog irons that could hold up a saw log.

column2: There was a clock on the middle of the mantelpiece, with a picture of a town painted on the bottom half of the glass front, and a round place in the middle of it for the sun, and you could see the pendulum swinging behind it.
column3: There was a clock on the middle of the mantelpiece, with a picture of a town painted on the bottom half of the glass front, and a round place in the middle of it for the sun, and you could see the pendulum swinging behind it.

column2: It was beautiful to hear that clock tick; and sometimes when one of these peddlers had been along and scoured her up and got her in good shape, she would start in and strike a hundred and fifty before she got tuckered out.
column3: It was beautiful to hear that clock tick; and sometimes when one of these peddlers had been along and scoured her up and got her in good shape, she would start in and strike a hundred and fifty before she got tuckered out.

column2: Well, there was a big outlandish parrot on each side of the clock, made out of something like chalk, and painted up gaudy.
column3: Well, there was a big outlandish parrot on each side of the clock, made out of something like chalk, and painted up gaudy.

column2: They squeaked through underneath.
column3: They squeaked through underneath.

column2: There was a couple of big wild-turkey-wing fans spread out behind those things.
column3: There was a couple of big wild turkey wing fans spread out behind those things.

column2: It come all the way from Philadelphia, they said.
column3: It come all the way from Philadelphia, they said.

column2: There was some books, too, piled up perfectly exact, on each corner of the table.
column3: There was some books, too, piled up perfectly exact, on each corner of the table.

column2: One was a big family Bible full of pictures.
column3: One was a big family Bible full of pictures.

column2: One was Pilgrim's Progress, about a man that left his family, it didn't say why.
column3: One was Pilgrim's Progress, about a man that left his family, it didn't say why.

column2: The statements was interesting, but tough.
column3: The statements was interesting, but tough.

column2: Another was Friendship's Offering, full of beautiful stuff and poetry; but I didn't read the poetry.
column3: Another was Friendship's Offering, full of beautiful stuff and poetry; but I didn't read the poetry.

column2: Another was Henry Clay's Speeches, and another was Dr. Gunn's Family Medicine, which told you all about what to do if a body was sick or dead.
column3: Another was Henry Clay's Speeches, and another was dr Gunn's Family Medicine, which told you all about what to do if a body was sick or dead.

column2: There was a hymn book, and a lot of other books.
column3: There was a hymn book, and a lot of other books.

column2: And there was nice split-bottom chairs, and perfectly sound, toonot bagged down in the middle and busted, like an old basket.
column3: And there was nice split bottom chairs, and perfectly sound, too  not bagged down in the middle and busted, like an old basket.

column2: But I reckoned that with her disposition she was having a better time in the graveyard.
column3: But I reckoned that with her disposition she was having a better time in the graveyard.

column2: She was at work on what they said was her greatest picture when she took sick, and every day and every night it was her prayer to be allowed to live till she got it done, but she never got the chance.
column3: She was at work on what they said was her greatest picture when she took sick, and every day and every night it was her prayer to be allowed to live till she got it done, but she never got the chance.

column2: Other times it was hid with a little curtain.
column3: Other times it was hid with a little curtain.

column2: This young girl kept a scrap-book when she was alive, and used to paste obituaries and accidents and cases of patient suffering in it out of the Presbyterian Observer, and write poetry after them out of her own head. It was very good poetry.
column3: This young girl kept a scrap book when she was alive, and used to paste obituaries and accidents and cases of patient suffering in it out of the Presbyterian Observer, and write poetry after them out of her own head. It was very good poetry.

column2: And did young Stephen sicken, And did young Stephen die?
column3: And did young Stephen sicken, And did young Stephen die?

column2: And did the sad hearts thicken, And did the mourners cry?
column3: And did the sad hearts thicken, And did the mourners cry?

column2: No whooping-cough did rack his frame, Nor measles drear with spots; Not these impaired the sacred name Of Stephen Dowling Bots.
column3: No whooping cough did rack his frame, Nor measles drear with spots; Not these impaired the sacred name Of Stephen Dowling Bots.

column2: Despised love struck not with woe That head of curly knots, Nor stomach troubles laid him low, Young Stephen Dowling Bots.
column3: Despised love struck not with woe That head of curly knots, Nor stomach troubles laid him low, Young Stephen Dowling Bots.

column2: O no. Then list with tearful eye, Whilst I his fate do tell.
column3: O no Then list with tearful eye, Whilst I his fate do tell.

column2: They got him out and emptied him; Alas it was too late; His spirit was gone for to sport aloft In the realms of the good and great.
column3: They got him out and emptied him; Alas it was too late; His spirit was gone for to sport aloft In the realms of the good and great.

column2: Buck said she could rattle off poetry like nothing.
column3: Buck said she could rattle off poetry like nothing.

column2: She warn't particular; she could write about anything you choose to give her to write about just so it was sadful. Every time a man died, or a woman died, or a child died, she would be on hand with her "tribute" before he was cold.
column3: She warn't particular; she could write about anything you choose to give her to write about just so it was sadful. Every time a man died, or a woman died, or a child died, she would be on hand with her "tribute" before he was cold.

column2: She called them tributes. The neighbors said it was the doctor first, then Emmeline, then the undertakerthe undertaker never got in ahead of Emmeline but once, and then she hung fire on a rhyme for the dead person's name, which was Whistler.
column3: She called them tributes. The neighbors said it was the doctor first, then Emmeline, then the undertaker  the undertaker never got in ahead of Emmeline but once, and then she hung fire on a rhyme for the dead person's name, which was Whistler.

column2: She warn't ever the same after that; she never complained, but she kinder pined away and did not live long.
column3: She warn't ever the same after that; she never complained, but she kinder pined away and did not live long.

column2: Poor thing, many's the time I made myself go up to the little room that used to be hers and get out her poor old scrap-book and read in it when her pictures had been aggravating me and I had soured on her a little.
column3: Poor thing, many's the time I made myself go up to the little room that used to be hers and get out her poor old scrap book and read in it when her pictures had been aggravating me and I had soured on her a little.

column2: I liked all that family, dead ones and all, and warn't going to let anything come between us.
column3: I liked all that family, dead ones and all, and warn't going to let anything come between us.

column2: Poor Emmeline made poetry about all the dead people when she was alive, and it didn't seem right that there warn't nobody to make some about her now she was gone; so I tried to sweat out a verse or two myself, but I couldn't seem to make it go somehow.
column3: Poor Emmeline made poetry about all the dead people when she was alive, and it didn't seem right that there warn't nobody to make some about her now she was gone; so I tried to sweat out a verse or two myself, but I couldn't seem to make it go somehow.

column2: Well, as I was saying about the parlor, there was beautiful curtains on the windows: white, with pictures painted on them of castles with vines all down the walls, and cattle coming down to drink.
column3: Well, as I was saying about the parlor, there was beautiful curtains on the windows: white, with pictures painted on them of castles with vines all down the walls, and cattle coming down to drink.

column2: The walls of all the rooms was plastered, and most had carpets on the floors, and the whole house was whitewashed on the outside.
column3: The walls of all the rooms was plastered, and most had carpets on the floors, and the whole house was whitewashed on the outside.

column2: It was a double house, and the big open place betwixt them was roofed and floored, and sometimes the table was set there in the middle of the day, and it was a cool, comfortable place.
column3: It was a double house, and the big open place betwixt them was roofed and floored, and sometimes the table was set there in the middle of the day, and it was a cool, comfortable place.
